title: 110_hr2571
content: Section 1 introduces special rules for nonbeverage products manufactured in a United States foreign trade zone, adding a new section 5063 to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. In a foreign trade zone, domestic distilled spirits can be used for nonbeverage product manufacturing without paying taxes if approved by the Secretary. Authorized manufacturers in the zone are exempt from taxes under section 5001. Unauthorized use of spirits incurs full tax liability under section 5001. The Secretary may require eligible persons to file a bond and permit, register annually, keep necessary records, and be subject to reporting and regulations to prevent tax fraud related to the use of distilled spirits in nonbeverage product manufacturing. The Secretary has the authority to examine records to ensure compliance with tax regulations. The Secretary may require eligible persons to file a bond, register annually, keep records, and be subject to regulations to prevent tax fraud related to the use of distilled spirits in nonbeverage product manufacturing. The Secretary has the authority to examine records to ensure compliance with tax regulations, including the demonstration of use in the manufacturing or production of nonbeverage products. Manufacturers or producers of nonbeverage products in foreign trade zones must comply with formula and manufacturing requirements. Failure to comply may result in penalties up to $1,000 per violation, unless due to reasonable cause. Penalties cannot exceed the tax amount that would have been determined without this section and must be paid within 30 days of notification by the Secretary. Manufacturers or producers of nonbeverage products in foreign trade zones must comply with formula and manufacturing requirements. Penalties for noncompliance can reach up to $1,000 per violation, but not exceeding the tax amount determined without this section. Payment is due within 30 days of notification by the Secretary. Authorized manufacturers and producers are those registered with the Secretary, agree to monthly reporting, and have received manufacturing authority from the United States Foreign Trade Zones Board. Nonbeverage products include medicines, medicinal preparations, and food products. Manufacturers of nonbeverage products in foreign trade zones must adhere to formula and manufacturing requirements. Penalties for noncompliance can be up to $1,000 per violation, payable within 30 days of notification. Authorized manufacturers must be registered with the Secretary, agree to monthly reporting, and have received manufacturing authority from the United States Foreign Trade Zones Board. Nonbeverage products include medicines, medicinal preparations, and food products. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include regulations for nonbeverage products. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include an exception for nonbeverage products manufactured in a United States foreign trade zone. This exception allows for nonbeverage products to be deposited in a foreign-trade zone without payment of tax as authorized by section 5063. The Foreign Trade Zones Act of 1934 is amended to allow products in foreign trade zones to be eligible for tax treatment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Distilled spirits for nonbeverage product manufacturing can be admitted to the trade zone in domestic status without taxes paid. Customs and Border Protection will follow admission procedures for products in foreign trade zones. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.
